H0.text: Oxygen is the gas B in the cycle in which a tree uses gas A to produce gas B, and an animal uses gas B to produce gas A.

H1.text: Nitrogen is the gas that a tree produces from gas A and that an animal uses to produce gas A in this cycle.

H2.text: Carbon dioxide is the gas B that a tree produces from gas A and that an animal uses to produce gas A in this cycle.

H3.text: Carbon monoxide is gas B in this cycle, where a tree uses gas A to produce carbon monoxide and an animal uses carbon monoxide to produce gas A.

A4.text: Photosynthesis releases oxygen into the atmosphere, while respiration, decay, and combustion remove it from the atmosphere.

A5.text: All eukaryotic organisms, including plants, animals, fungi, algae and most protists, need oxygen for cellular respiration, a process that extracts chemical energy by the reaction of oxygen with organic molecules derived from food and releases carbon dioxide as a waste product.
